captions.text:
Christ, do I enjoy multiplayer-only games 
and being around other human beings in

general. Syncing up schedules, employing basic 
social skills, smelling each other&#39;s armpits,

having to wear trousers, oh, it&#39;s just the 
fucking best. And boy do I appreciate the output

of Josef Fares and Hazelight Studios, consisting 
entirely of narrative games that are strictly and

unmovably two-player only. Just as much as I 
appreciate wedding DJs trying to convince me

that I really secretly want to humiliate myself 
on the dance floor. First they did A Way Out,

which certainly made me look for A Way Out 
of having to play this fucking awful game,

then, in perhaps the sharpest my opinion on 
a studio has ever U-turned between games,

they did It Takes Two, as in It Takes Two tabs of 
blotter acid to make something as fun and creative

as this. Now, let&#39;s hope I won&#39;t be Split on this 
Fiction or whatever. While I hate having to go to

the basement to reactivate the homunculus, 
I respect the strict two-player thing. At

least it knows what it wants to be and can be 
optimized for its unique dynamic. Better than

shit like Helldivers going, &quot;No, really, you 
can totally play this single-player and it&#39;ll

be just as good&quot; while smiling insincerely and 
making uncomfortable glances at my shillelagh.

Split Fiction is much as one should 
expect from a follow-up to It Takes Two;

at its core, it&#39;s a perfectly competently made 3D 
platformer, and every section introduces a new,

interesting brace of puzzle/combat mechanics 
that pay off the two-player dynamic. One player

gets a climb ability, the other gets 
a glide ability; one gets magnetism,

the other gets repulsion; one holds a big piece 
of toast, the other can manipulate vegemite,

etc. It&#39;s fun to get through the challenges, 
the homunculus seemed happy to be involved,

and no one idea hangs around long enough to get 
boring. I wouldn&#39;t say it reaches the heights

of creativity It Takes Two managed; there&#39;s 
no wing-walking squirrel fights or stuffed

elephant torture, but if you&#39;re looking for a fun 
platformer to enjoy with your personal homunculus,

then I recommend it. Right. That&#39;s what I wanted 
to get out of the way first. I will now spend the

rest of my time complaining about the plot because 
all I remembered about It Takes Two was that it

was fun. I nodded along with everyone else when 
it won Game of the Year. And I slightly resent

Split Fiction for reminding me that the writing 
in Hazelight&#39;s games has always been kinda shit.

The premise is, we play as Zoe and Mia, two 
young adult fiction authors with nothing in

common except how easy they find it to enter their 
names on high score tables, who are invited to a

tech demo by a sinister corporation ostensibly 
to have their stories published as immersive

VR experiences. But it turns out the VR machine&#39;s 
actual purpose is to suck all the creativity juice

out of their heads to be used for evil and profit 
and evil profit in a slightly clumsy analogy for

AI copyright disputes. But something goes wrong, 
and Zoe and Mia end up stuck in the same machine

together, having to live out each other&#39;s stories, 
which will somehow destroy the machine. And show

that the power of wealthy tech bros will always be 
defeated by the power of solidarity, friendship,

and young adult fiction. There are so many 
fundamental flaws in the central premise

I&#39;m not sure where to start; suffice to 
say the heroes hardly need to destroy

the machine because after the company tries 
to publish all the stories they&#39;ve nicked,

they&#39;re going to get sued to oblivion anyway 
by about 9,000 different copyright holders.

My homunculus and I lost count of all the other 
video games briefly referenced by the constantly

changing mechanics. Prince of Persia, Zelda, 
Gradius, Space Harrier, Panzer Dragoon, Metroid.

And I don&#39;t know why this is all presented 
as stories the protagonists have written;

they must have been really bloody boring to read. 
&quot;And then they shot an enemy. And then they shot

another enemy. And then they shot a third enemy. 
And then they slid down a hill on their bums

for the nineteenth fucking time.&quot; It might have 
made more sense if the protagonists were indie

game designers, although a story about naive 
young indie devs being held down and milked

for all their good ideas by a soulless corporate 
machine might have hit a bit close to home for

a game published by EA. But okay, it&#39;s a silly 
premise, so what? It&#39;s a fun, facetious game.

Not everything has to be Sophie&#39;s fucking Choice. 
The thing is, it&#39;s a plot about on the level of a

subpar young adult novel, primarily about subpar 
young adult novel writers and how they&#39;re the most

creative and interesting people in the world. And 
it does something I find very irksome in games,

and that&#39;s using dialogue between its 
characters to give itself compliments.

&quot;Wow, what an impressive view,&quot; they might say. &quot;I 
hope the art team that put it together negotiate a

higher salary after this.&quot; Or, &quot;What? We have 
to ride on the back of a dragon? How did you

come up with something THAT creative, you insane, 
twisted fucking genius?&quot; I said in my Alan Wake 2

video that any creative work about the power of 
creativity is going to be inherently up itself,

but you don&#39;t need to sledgehammer it home. I 
hate it whenever a work of fiction ends with

the protagonists writing a really successful 
book about it with the same name as the work

of fiction. The fucking Game of Thrones finale did 
that. And if you can only take one piece of advice

for all your future endeavors, let it be to never 
do anything that the Game of Thrones finale did.

But the stringiest, worms-riddled dog turd running 
through the center of this apple turnover for me

was the characters. Ooh, they&#39;re chalk and cheese, 
they are; one&#39;s a city girl, one&#39;s a country girl;

one&#39;s dad is a mechanic, the other&#39;s dad is a 
sheep. The game will tell you that country girl

is optimistic and extroverted, but she comes 
across more as a smug, flaky busybody. And

city girl is pessimistic and introverted, but SHE 
comes across more as an unlikeable, spiky asshole.

The central wedge between them is that one 
only writes hackneyed sci-fi and the other

only writes hackneyed fantasy, and they 
spend the whole fucking game being judgy

of each other for it. I wish there&#39;d been a 
third lead who was like a literary fiction

writer who could point out that every fucking 
book shop in the world groups those two genres

together for a reason, and they&#39;re both equally 
frivolous twats. The dialogue&#39;s also overwritten

with frivolous twat A and B feeling the 
need to comment on fucking everything,

constantly telling without showing and describing 
their personalities at each other. You know what,

though? I don&#39;t think I&#39;d change it. Because 
in the end, part of the fun of the game,

and indeed of composing this nasty review, lay 
in me taking the piss out of the characters

throughout every dialogue scene, and the mandatory 
second player meant I always had someone to riff

with. And if that was the intended experience, 
then Josef Fares is a fucking evil genius,

but I doubt it. In brief, you&#39;re a great game 
designer, Josef; now for fuck&#39;s sake, get

someone else to write the story for your next 
one. Hit me up; I&#39;m a published author. That&#39;s

why I found it slightly offensive the way 
Split Fiction pushes the lazy notion that

people only ever write about adversity or horror 
because of unresolved personal trauma. You don&#39;t

need to be fucked in the head to write fucked 
up things. We&#39;re not all Neil bloody Gaiman.
